content.description: The crux is at the top when the holds thin out. You might find yourself one crystal in each hand, sub zero temps help.
content.location: Face climb seven feet directly left of Heaven arete. Start on holds at five feet. Climb straight up using crystals.

content.description: Rugosa tackles the arete just left of the Loaf, starting low and moving up on very rough slopers and crimps.
content.location: The overhanging arete left of the big overhang

content.description: Start siting under roof, left hand side pull and right hand crimp. The crux is getting over the buldge and getting all the weight onto your feet.
content.location: The route is the first obvious overhang you see while hiking up to the lower large boulder.

content.description: The crux is reaching the glued pocket and finishing the problem.
content.location: On the backside, center, of the lower of the stone stones you will find this problem. Half way through the route you will match a loaf, hence the name. Start low matching hands in seam, climb straight.

content.description: Heaven climbs the very obvious and aesthetic southwest corner of the Cornerstone. After a crimpy and sharp start, the climbing eases up considerably with a tall, slightly balancy, but very fun finish. This was the very first problem put up here, requiring quite a lot of cleaning. It was done in a pre-pad era so it was TR-ed first, then soloed. With modern pads, a ground-up ascent is pretty reasonable
content.protection: Two or three good-sized pads should be sufficent

content.description: Not actually on the Cornerstone boulder, but on the boulder that's behind the route "Rugosa/Yunker". Climb up the clean-ish crack ann arete on the left corner of the slab opposite the Cornerstone boulder. Sit start isn't too hard and makes for a better route.

Overhanging project that follows a very slopey lip to the sketchiest top out since the war of 1812. very sharp slopers and haggard crimps. Still a project but possibly a v5-7 depending on the beta. The Top out is incredibly sketchy and is probably the crux.
content.protection: 1-2 pads, there is a tree that warrants some caution.
content.location: Start facing the "Subzero" route, spin 180 degrees and you will see an overhanging face directly behind you. Start with the right hand on the small crimp about a foot to the left of a large sloped shelf and the left hand pinching a very small undercling ( You may have to do some searching for this), continue along the sloped diagonal lip utilizing various crimps and pinches to top out at the peak of the boulder

pathTokens: Bradbury Mountain State Park (CLOSED to Climbing Oct '17)

content.description: The smaller and lower of the two primary boulders at Bradbury Mountain. It is is easily identifiable by the striking 20 foot arete of Heaven.
